title: Inspector accused of having sex with stalking victim has earned £125,000 while suspended
text:
Sussex Police Inspector Tony Lumb has been suspended on full pay for two and a half years

A police inspector accused of sleeping with vulnerable women he met while on duty has earned £125,000 from the taxpayer while suspended for more than two years - as his force continues to drag its feet over his misconduct hearing.

Brighton-based Sussex Police officer Tony Lumb, 52, was arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office in March 2017, interviewed under criminal caution, and suspended on full pay.

He is accused of engaging in improper relationships with multiple women in Sussex in the course of his duties.

Nicola Brookes, 52, a stalking victim who met Lumb in 2011, has waived her right to anonymity to accuse Lumb of leaving her feeling like 'a deformed piece of meat'.

In November 2017 the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) said it had found evidence to suggest Lumb might have committed a criminal offence and referred a file to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS).

The IOPC investigation also found Lumb has a case to answer for gross misconduct and referred the matter to Sussex Police to schedule a disciplinary hearing.

The CPS dropped the case in October 2018, concluding there was insufficient evidence to charge Insp Lumb with a criminal offence, and Sussex Police said he would face disciplinary proceedings in due course.

But a year on there is still no date set for Insp Lumb's gross misconduct hearing.

Meanwhile the Inspector, who earns between £50,000 and £55,000 a year, remains suspended on full pay.

The police precept on council tax in Sussex for a Band D home is £189.91 after a recent 12 per cent increase, meaning Inspector Lumb's salary during his two and a half years suspended has swallowed the entire contribution of 650 such taxpayers.

Nicola Brookes says Sussex Police's handling of the 30 month process has shattered her faith in the police and the justice system

Ms Brookes, a disabled Crohn's disease sufferer who claims Mr Lumb manipulated her over a period of years after meeting her while on duty, ultimately violating her trust, called the ongoing delays a 'farce'.

She said: 'The police have had this case since January 2017. He has been suspended for two and a half years.

'You would think Sussex Police would have prepared his gross misconduct hearing by now.'

She told MailOnline she had completely lost trust and confidence in the justice system as a result of the protracted affair and Sussex Police's handling of the matter.

A spokeswoman for Sussex Police said: 'Anthony Lumb, a police inspector based at Brighton, is being investigated for misconduct in public office and will face a gross misconduct hearing at a date to be fixed.

'Inspector Lumb was suspended at the point of allegations in 2017 and the case referred to the Independent Office of Police Conduct (IOPC) for full investigation.

'In 2018, the IOPC subsequently directed Sussex Police to progress a gross misconduct hearing following a review by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS).

'The CPS concluded, following appeal, there was no criminal case to answer in July of this year. Sussex Police is now in the process of preparing the hearing, scheduled for five days, which as required will be led by a legally-qualified chair.

'Inspector Lumb is suspended on full pay, as is mandated by national police regulations.'
description: Sussex Police Inspector Tony Lumb, 52, was arrested in March of 2017. He is accused of inappropriately sleeping with women he met while on duty.
